title: What is wrong with writing God in small letters (god)? - Quora

response.answer_text: The two words, God and god, are different words with different meanings. The word god is a regular noun, like deity, entity, being, and lemon. It refers to a member of a class of supernatural beings which are pervasive forces in the universe, and for the most part, includes beings the person using the word does not believe exists The word God is a name, like naming your dog Dog. It refers to a specific god, namely the one from the Abrahamic faiths: Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Mormon, and a handful of obscure others. If you’re talking about Thor, then you use god. If you’re talking about Yahweh, Jehovah, Jesus, Allah etc, you use God. So, that’s a start on what’s wrong with it. It’s very likely ungrammatical, the cases where you would build your sentence the same using a specific name and a general noun aren’t all that common. But there’s a bigger point here. The problem is that using the two terms interchangeably leads to logical errors, sometimes deliberately, sometimes accidentally, but at any rate, you end up saying things that look logical, that sound correct when you say them out loud, but which don’t actually follow, visibly so if you use the right capitalization, not so if you use the terms willy-nilly. For example: When I say god, I mean the force that binds us all together, love. You do believe in love don’t you? Now, that’s something I could agree with. I mean, it’s an odd use of the word, but I do believe it exists, and if calling it “god” makes sense to you, fine, we both believe in that kind of “god”. But then you say “So you should come to church with me tomorrow and accept god into your heart”… and by that you mean God, as in Jesus, Father, Holy Ghost, as in the deity who wants to be praised because after he slaughtered all but 8 humans he made a rainbow… not some vague non-athropomorophised feeling of love and brotherhood, but a very specific, and very evil, fictional entity. It’s like getting me to agree that “Tom” as in Tom Hiddleston, is a great actor, and then asking me to put “Tom,” as in Tom Arnold, in my next movie. Look, just because I like one Tom doesn’t mean I like the other. Similarly, you can talk all you want about gods, but don’t confuse them with God.

There is nothing wrong with not capitalizing the word “god” in certain contexts. Being an atheist, I have used the un-capitalized version many times, although it is best to refer to “God” as the Judeo-Christian/Islamic god/deity to avoid having to deal with this dilemma. Whether to capitalize the word or not can get pretty tricky, since not all people believe in the monotheistic, all-knowing god that comes from the Bible. My rule of thumb for this goes as follows: In some contexts, “God” can be referred to as if it was any other name, since it is a proper noun. Example: God is nice. Just like how you would say “Joe is nice” or “He is nice.” However, I try to avoid this form as much as possible because it indicates that the person writing the sentence acknowledges that there is one, all-knowing god, and that this god should be respected by capitalizing its name as “God”. In other contexts, “God” does not not have to be capitalized, such as in my former sentence when I said “not all people believe in the monotheistic, all-knowing god that comes from the Bible”. This is because in this context, “God” is not a proper noun and can be treated like any other noun. We know this because it can be interchanged with the word “deity” or “being”. I remember a few years ago I asked my English teacher (who was very religious since I went to a private Catholic high school) the same question and he said that it is ultimately a personal choice, although most people who speak the English language capatalize the word “god” because that is traditionally how it has been written. Keep in mind that Christianity is the world’s largest religion, and since English is the most dominant language in the Western world, many people choose to write it as “God” as a sign of reverence. However, it is important to take note of the grammatical context, since writing “god” can be grammatically incorrect if you are using it as a proper noun.

Wording of the question when I answered: What is wrong with writing God in small letters (god)? Not a thing. It is a Christian conceit that there are no other gods but their god (they’re only off by one) so they choose to call their god, “God.” That makes it a proper name and subject to capitalization. But Christians see the capitalization as a mark of respect, rather than a matter of grammar. They also capitalize He, His, and Him, when referring to their god, although these are pronouns and do not require capital letters. I use lower case g for god, and when referring to the Christian god, I call it “the Christian god,” or “the god called ‘God.’”

My experience is that it's usually invoked as a generic name by people who haven't clearly defined their god or god's, which often leads to confusion in discussions, even on Quora. It's much more informative to speak of Jesus, Allah, the Trinity, etc. than to say, “do you believe in God?” My feeling has always been, if you don't have a definition of your god clear enough to explain to a child, you probably shouldn't try.

There’s nothing wrong with it, per se. Writing “God” with a capital “G” indicates that one’s referring specifically to the Christian god. Writing “god” with a lower-case “g” indicates that one’s referring to any god, not specifically the God of the Bible. This is because “God” is a name, but “god” simply refers to a non-specific creator deity.

Proper nouns have a capital letter. Common nouns (such as “god”) begin with a lowercase letter, but in English they must be preceded by a determiner: a god, that god, your god, and so on. If we were talking about rabbits, you might say I saw a rabbit or Have you met my rabbit? or That rabbit has been eating my flowers, but you can't say *I saw rabbit without a determiner. On the other hand, you might have a rabbit called Rabbit, as in the Winnie-the-Pooh stories. Then you could write Pooh was going to visit Rabbit, but you'd need the capital letter.
